title: Grilled Swordfish With Pineapple-plantain Chutney
summary: Grilled Swordfish With Pineapple-plantain Chutney is a gluten free main course. This recipe makes 1 servings with 2529 calories, 184g of protein, and 139g of fat each. For $25.81 per serving, this recipe covers 68% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. It can be enjoyed any time, but it is especially good for The Fourth Of July. This recipe is liked by 1 foodies and cooks. Head to the store and pick up shallot, plantain, wine, and a few other things to make it today. To use up the plantain you could follow this main course with the Plantain Cupcakes as a dessert. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 1 hour. It is brought to you by Recipezaar. Taking all factors into account, this recipe earns a spoonacular score of 69%, which is good. If you like this recipe, you might also like recipes such as Grilled Swordfish with Pineapple- Peach Salsa, Plantain Fritters with a Spicy Sweet & Sour Peach and Bell Pepper Chutney, and The Secret Ingredient (Mango Chutney): Sweet-Hot Chutney-Grilled Chicken.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are great choices for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Zind-Humbrecht Calcaire Pinot Gris with a 4.7 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 46 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Zind-Humbrecht Calcaire Pinot Gris
productMatches.description: Bright yellow/gold color, quite luminous. Superb smoky toasty nose, typical for this grape on limestone in Alsace (no new oak in our wines, just very long total lees contact). Some light reductive aromas that actually fit the style of dry Pinot-Gris. The palate is rich and creamy, with a velvety texture yet fully dry. It is an easy wine to drink now as there is no unnecessary weight. The finish is nice and round but fully dry. The complex limestone blend brings great acid balance and a certain weight. It should develop very nicely over the next few years.

instructions: For Chutney: Melt 2 tablespoons butter in heavy medium skillet over medium-high heat. Add plantain; saut until golden, about 8 minutes. Remove from heat. Mix pineapple, 1/2 cup wine, stock and chili in heavy medium saucepan. Stir over medium heat until most of liquid evaporates and pineapple is soft, about 10 minutes. Add plantain and stir to blend. Season with salt and pepper.For fish: Prepare barbecue (medium-high heat) or preheat broiler. Mix lime juice, shallots and honey in blender. Gradually add oil and blend well. Brush mixture liberally over fish. Season fish with salt and pepper.Grill fish until cooked through, basting with lime mixture, about 4 minutes per side. Serve with chutney.

steps.step: For Chutney: Melt 2 tablespoons butter in heavy medium skillet over medium-high heat.
Add plantain; saut until golden, about 8 minutes.
Mix pineapple, 1/2 cup wine, stock and chili in heavy medium saucepan. Stir over medium heat until most of liquid evaporates and pineapple is soft, about 10 minutes.
Add plantain and stir to blend. Season with salt and pepper.For fish: Prepare barbecue (medium-high heat) or preheat broiler.
Mix lime juice, shallots and honey in blender. Gradually add oil and blend well.
Brush mixture liberally over fish. Season fish with salt and pepper.Grill fish until cooked through, basting with lime mixture, about 4 minutes per side.
